newsitem.title: INDIA: Key ally backs India PM in war on corruption.
newsitem.headline: Key ally backs India PM in war on corruption.

text.p: India's influential Congress party on Saturday joined a renewed campaign launched by Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral to fight corruption, saying it would offer its backing to two laws that could help in the process.

The Congress party, which has ruled India for all but four years since independence in 1947, is a make-or-break ally for Gujral's three-month-old United Front coalition. The alliance is in a minority in parliament.

"We and our party are in the forefront of the fight against corruption,..." Congress president Sitaram Kesri said a day after Gujral issued a call against corruption during an address marking 50 years of India's independence from Britain.
Gujral's call reflected widespread public opinion that politicians as a class had let down the country by encouraging corruption.
Kesri said he was ready to back Gujral's measures to legislate the appointment of a Lok Pal (ombudsman) to probe public figures and a law to provide freedom of information.
"I am ready to support it tomorrow. Our party will support this immediately," Kesri said in response to a question at a news conference in the Indian capital. "Let them bring it on Monday."
The United Front changed its leader to please Kesri after his party withdrew its support for incumbent H.D. Deve Gowda, whose government lost a confidence vote in April.
Kesri said he signalled his party's intention to fight corruption by nominating two leaders with a clean image to the party's decision-making Congress Working Committee.

He said he appointed former finance minister Manmohan Singh and southern leader A.K. Antony to the 20-member panel, to which 10 members were directly elected by delegates at a party plenary earlier this month.
The Congress president fills up 10 posts. Kesri said he would name eight members later.
"I have appointed two clean candidates to the CWC. The nomination of the two gives a message," he said.
The Congress party has itself fallen prey to corruption scandals. Last year, it suffered its worst defeat in history widely linked to corruption scandals.
Seven Congress ministers had resigned in January 1996 after federal police slapped bribery charges on them in a $18-million illegal foreign exchange scandal.
Kesri replaced the then party president P.V. Narasimha Rao in September after a court framed charges against him in a criminal cheating case.
Rao says he is innocent, but resigned as party chief in the face of intense pressures to quit.
Earlier on Saturday, Gujral kept up momentum from his speech on Friday, when he had asked countrymen to launch a "satyagraha," or civil disobedience campaign, against corruption.
He asked industrialists at a conference to expose corrupt businessmen in their midst, and announced the setting up of a special cell in his office to deal directly with complaints against corruption.
On Friday, he told the nation in a televised address from the 17th century Red Fort that bribe-giving was as much to blame as bribe-taking.
Gujral echoed President K.R. Narayanan, who made a speech at a midnight session of parliament on Friday to mark the anniversary, in calling for a mass movement to end bribery.
